description: Easy - The Paradox of Victory and Traditional Economy

questions.question: What fundamental problem did Rome's victory in the Punic Wars create?
options: Rome's military forces were exhausted from decades of warfare
Wealth from conquest concentrated in elite hands rather than distributing evenly across society
Rome lost control of Mediterranean territories to rival powers
Rome's agricultural production increased beyond what the population could consume

questions.question: What was a fundus in traditional Roman agriculture?
options: A large commercial grain farm operated by enslaved workers
A government warehouse storing grain for the military
A marketplace where farmers sold their produce to urban traders
A small family-owned farm of 5-10 acres worked primarily by family labor
questions.text_reference: Section 2 - The Traditional Roman Economy: The Smallholding Farmer

questions.question: Who was the paterfamilias in Roman agricultural society?
options: The head of a household who owned and worked his own fundus independently
A hired manager overseeing enslaved workers on large estates
A government official responsible for distributing public land
A wealthy merchant who purchased grain from multiple farmers

questions.question: Why was the combination of independent farmer and citizen-soldier important to Rome?
options: It provided Rome with a small professional military force that could be deployed anywhere
It created a farming class dependent on government subsidies and support
It gave farmers personal motivation to defend Rome while providing reliable military forces
It allowed Rome to avoid using enslaved workers in agriculture entirely
questions.text_reference: Section 2 - Why This System Mattered Politically

questions.question: How long did the First Punic War last?
options: 12 years
23 years
40 years
17 years
questions.text_reference: Section 3 - The Punic Wars and the Displacement of Farmers

questions.question: What was one major consequence of extended military service during the Punic Wars?
options: Farmers became wealthy from military pay and could expand their estates
The government compensated farmers for lost agricultural production
Enslaved workers were freed and given farmland to replace displaced farmers
Unattended farms deteriorated and returning veterans faced financial ruin and debt
questions.text_reference: Section 3 - The Problem of Military Service

questions.question: What economic advantage did latifundia have over small family farms?
options: They produced higher quality crops with better flavor and nutrition
They required fewer workers but generated higher profits through slave labor and scale
They could produce diverse crops unlike small farms focused on single products
They received special tax exemptions and government support not available to small farmers
questions.text_reference: Section 3 - The Growth of Slavery and the Collapse of Small Farming

questions.question: What does the Latin word latifundium literally mean?
options: Slave-worked estate
Aristocratic property
Export-oriented farm
Wide lands

questions.question: Who typically managed a latifundium on behalf of its wealthy owner?
options: The owner's eldest son who lived on the property
A hired overseer called a vilicus who managed day-to-day operations
An elected government official supervising agricultural production
A group of enslaved workers who made collective decisions

questions.question: What was the primary reason Rome's cities grew dramatically in the 2nd century BCE?
options: Rome's population increased through higher birth rates among existing city dwellers
Rome conquered new territories and forced their populations to relocate to Rome
Rural farmers migrated to cities after losing their land to latifundia expansion
Enslaved workers were freed and concentrated in urban centers
